tossups.question: This politician published an article declaring “We want no Caesars” decrying his own rise to power under the pseudonym “Chanakya.” The Henderson Brooks report claimed that this politician’s military was underprepared for a war that was preceded by his Forward Policy. A scandal involving procurement of jeeps during that war led this leader’s defense minister, V. K. (*) Menon, to resign. Groups like the Monkees and the Beatles popularized this leader’s namesake style of jacket in the 1960s. This man claimed that “The light has gone out of our lives” after the assassination of his mentor by Nathuram Godse and gave the “Tryst with Destiny” speech after his country gained independence from the UK in 1947. For 10 points, name this first prime minister of India.
tossups.answer: Jawaharlal Nehru <ML, World History>

tossups.question: This poem employs the image of a bishop “waving a condom full of black-beetles” in a hell “without dignity, without tragedy.” Lord Palmerston advises, “Begin where you are” in a section of this poem that heavily cites the Confucian Book of Rites. The first Bollingen Prize was awarded to a section of this poem, whose “Fifth Decad” includes a piece arguing that Renaissance artists prospered only in a world without usura. This poem, whose (*) “China” section quotes many Chinese ideograms, begins “And then went down to the ship” and is divided into sections like “Rock Drill.” After its author was arrested for pro-Fascist broadcasts over Rome Radio, he wrote a section of this poem while imprisoned in Pisa. For 10 points, name this book-length Modernist poem by Ezra Pound.
tossups.answer: The Cantos <NC, Poetry>

tossups.question: In bar 5 of an aria from an opera with this name in the title, three rising C major broken inverted triads in a dotted rhythm mimic a bugle or march. This name is sung in the middle of an aria that opens with a long C, repeats the short notes D B C three times, then falls from high E to low E. The overture of an opera titled for this name opens in D major with soft scurrying by unison strings and bassoons. The orchestra rests as this name quickly (*) repeats 9 times on the notes E D C in a baritone’s entrance aria announcing “make way.” This intrepid character from a Beaumarchais (“bo-mar-SHAY”) trilogy sings “Non più andrai” (“known pyoo on-DRY”) in Mozart’s first Da Ponte opera. This character helps Almaviva woo Rosina and sings “Largo al factotum” in Rossini’s Barber of Seville. For 10 points, name this protagonist of a Mozart comic opera about his “Marriage.”
tossups.answer: Figaro [accept Figaro’s aria; accept The Marriage of Figaro or Le nozze di Figaro; prompt on The Barber of Seville or Il barbiere di Siviglia or barber; prompt on “Largo al factotum” or factotum] <OL, Classical/Opera>

tossups.question: The third secret of Our Lady of Fátima predicted this country “spread[ing] her errors throughout the world” unless it was consecrated to the Immaculate Heart of Mary. Among this country’s many New Martyrs from the 20th century was a priest named Hermogenes. This country, which demolished the Church of Christ the Saviour to expropriate its gold, forced many of its youth to join the (*) League of Militant Atheists and set up many “anti-religious museums” as part of an effort to promote “scientific atheism.” This country failed in its plan to settle many Jews to the east in the Jewish Autonomous Oblast. For 10 points, name this country whose dominant Orthodox Church was answerable to the Communist Party of Leonid Brezhnev.
tossups.answer: Russia [or the Russian Federation or Russian Empire; or USSR; or Soviet Union; or Union of Soviet Socialist Republics; or SSSR or Soyuz Sovietskikh Sotsialisticheskikh Respublik] <AA, Religion>

tossups.question: A pink bird and several of these animals gather around a dark woman with glowing eyes in an Henri Rousseau painting with a solitary full moon at the top left. The pose of a reclining nude’s legs is mimicked by a pink one of these animals found to the right of two lions in another Rousseau painting, titled The Dream. A tiled blue wall decorated with calligraphy forms the background of a painting in which a nude boy with his back to the viewer holds two of these animals. That painting by (*) Jean-Léon Gérôme (“zhay-ROME”) titled for these animals is on the original cover of Edward Said’s (“sa-EED’s”) Orientalism. The ouroboros (“yur-uh-BOR-us”) symbol shows one of these animals, which feature in most scenes of The Death of Cleopatra. For 10 points, what kind of animal has an apple in its mouth in Henri Rousseau’s Eve?
tossups.answer: snake [accept serpent; accept specific varieties such as pythons or cobras or asps] <AR, Painting/Sculpture>

tossups.question: This is the largest persistent feature that is confined by bands composed of Taylor columns, according to F. H. Busse’s “deep model.” In May 2019, amateur Anthony Wesley took a photo that appears to show “blades” and “flakes” on this feature, which is the largest such object in the “System II” latitude and has a “junior” counterpart called Oval BA. True color photos of this feature were taken at a distance of 8,000 kilometers in 2017 with the aid of an “auroral mapper” by NASA’s (*) Juno mission. The first observations to call it “permanent” were made by Giovanni Cassini. Time-lapse photos from Voyager 1 confirmed that this system, which is found between two jet streams and is about the diameter of the Earth, moves in an anticyclonic manner. For 10 points, name this large storm on Jupiter named for its color.
tossups.answer: Great Red Spot [prompt on spot; prompt on Jupiter or Jupiter’s atmosphere until “Jupiter” is read; prompt on the storm on Jupiter until “storm” is read] <WA, Astronomy>

tossups.question: This river is the ultimate drain of most of a highland region littered with many tabletop mountains called tepuis (“teh-POO-ees”). Competition from the spectacled caiman (“KAY-min”) has helped drive this river’s namesake species of huge crocodile to critically endangered status. This river’s name means “a place to paddle” in the language of the local Warao people, who travel on it in boats. The so-called Casiquiare (“ka-see-kee-AH-ray”) Canal flows [emphasize] south from this river into the (*) Rio Negro, linking it to a larger system to the south. This river provides most drainage to plains called the llanos (“YAH-nos”) and the rest of the area covered by the Guiana Shield. It empties into the Atlantic Ocean directly opposite from the island of Trinidad. For 10 points, name this major river of Venezuela.
tossups.answer: Orinoco River <WA, Geography>

tossups.question: Gunnar Kaufman excels in this activity before becoming a renowned poet and self-described “Black messiah” in Paul Beatty’s 1996 debut novel. The protagonist of a different novel dies of a heart attack while performing this activity in Florida, where he fled after having sex with his daughter-in-law. The protagonist uses his skill in this activity to stop a grenade from killing some Vietnamese children at an airport at the end of (*) A Prayer for Owen Meany. A novel opens with the 26-year-old protagonist stopping in an alley to participate in this activity with some teenagers before going home to his wife Janice. In a series of novels, a salesman who once excelled in this activity is depicted as “rich” and “at rest.” For 10 points, John Updike’s character Harry Angstrom is nicknamed “Rabbit” while a high-school star in what sport?
tossups.answer: basketball [accept descriptions such as shooting hoops or dunkin’ on ’em; prompt on sports] <RK, Long Fiction>

tossups.question: The evolution of hereditary kingship among this region’s peoples is examined in a book that puts forth “Newton’s third law of empires” by Peter Heather. Those peoples of this region were divided into Ingaevones (“ing-eye-WO-nays”), Herminones (“hair-mih-NO-nays”), and Istaevones (“ist-eye-WO-nays”) by a classical author who described how a reputation as “lazy fools” had befallen the Cherusci (“khair-OO-skee”). An emperor supposedly bashed his head against the palace walls at night after a (*) defeat in this region, wailing “Quintilius Varus, give me back my legions!” This region titles an ethnography by Tacitus, who numbered the Marcomanni and Lombards among its peoples, and, like most Romans, roughly defined it as being north of the Danube and east of the Rhine. For 10 points, name this region where many Romans were slain at the Battle of Teutoburg Forest.
tossups.answer: Germania [or Germany] <JM, Ancient/Archaeology>

tossups.question: A 2019 Science paper reported the kinase PfCLK3 as a novel drug target in members of this genus. It’s not trypanosoma, but members of this genus have around 60 var genes that they can switch on and off to express different versions of their PfEMP1 protein on host cell surfaces. In host cells, this genus undergoes 13 to 14 rounds of cell division in schizogony (“skizz-OGG-uh-nee”), which ultimately produces a multinucleate schizont (“SKIZZ-ont”). An unusual peroxide bridge is found in a sesquiterpene (“SESS-qui-TER-peen”) lactone drug that treats infection by members of this genus, called (*) artemisinin. The ovale (“oh-VAL-ay”), vivax, and falciparum (“fal-SIP-uh-rum”) members of this genus most commonly infect humans, and are all carried by the common Anopheles (“uh-NOFF-uh-leez”) mosquito. For 10 points, name this genus of eukaryotes that are responsible for causing malaria.
tossups.answer: Plasmodium <RN, Biology: Immuno>

tossups.question: It’s not Spain, but a member of the political minority is compared to that of a bull and Christ as he dies in a story from this country by a member of its “Generation of 1837.” “The Slaughter Yard” and an earlier non-fiction book employ a dichotomy of “civilization and barbarism” to critique a dictator of this country. A character from this country goes on the run after killing a black man in a knife fight, leading him to be challenged by the man’s brother in an all-night singing contest. The Parisian (*) Serpent Club appears in a novel from this country that details Horacio Oliviera’s search for La Maga and includes a “Table of Instructions” explaining how it can be read nonlinearly. Martín Fierro and Julio Cortázar are from, for 10 points, what Latin American country, whose literature often features gauchos that roam the Pampas?
tossups.answer: Argentina [or Argentine Republic; or República Argentina] <AR, Misc Lit>

tossups.question: The tail of a density distribution modelling one of these structures is often characterized by the “skin thickness,” across which that density drops from 90 percent to 10 percent. Danysz (“DAH-nish”) and Pniewski (“p’nee-EV-skee”) discovered one of these objects containing a hyperon. Maria Goeppert-Mayer (“GUR-putt-MY-er”) developed a model of these structures that allows for the prediction of a sequence of numbers characterizing them, including (*) 28, 50, 82, and 126. The motion of these objects is considered to be negligible in the Born–Oppenheimer approximation. The shell model describes these objects, which are particularly stable at “magic numbers.” The existence of these objects was deduced in an experiment in which alpha particles were fired at gold foil by Ernst Rutherford. For 10 points, name these structures composed of protons and neutrons.
tossups.answer: atomic nucleus [or atomic nuclei] <WA, Physics>

tossups.question: Every year during this holiday, people meet on Cole’s Hill to commemorate Frank James’s speech on it. On this holiday, a Coast Guard blockade was blocked by Ron Craig’s ship, allowing John Trudell’s people to pass. Creedence Clearwater Revival supported that protest on this holiday with the donation of a boat. The UAINE created a National Day of Mourning on this holiday. After a letter campaign by (*) Sarah Josepha Hale to Abraham Lincoln, this holiday became a national holiday in 1864. Traditionally, Native American groups have protested it by painting Plymouth Rock red or occupying a replica of the Mayflower. For 10 points, name this holiday, commemorating Squanto’s sharing of food, celebrated on the fourth Thursday of November.
tossups.answer: Thanksgiving Day [accept National Day of Mourning until read; accept Unthanksgiving Day] <ML, US History>

tossups.question: When a messenger sent by this goddess killed a pheasant, the arrow landed at this goddess’s feet, after which a god standing next to her got pissed and threw the arrow into the messenger’s chest, killing him. This goddess, who employs a three-footed crow as a messenger, sent her grandson from the plain of heaven across a bridge to become the ruler of earth. In one story, her curiosity was piqued by the sound of laughter from several gods watching a bad (*) striptease performed on top of a bathtub. When this goddess sent Ninigi to rule earth, she gave him three gifts: a precious jewel, a “grasscutter” sword, and a mirror thought to be kept at the Ise (“ee-say”) shrine in which she saw her own reflection after emerging from a cave. For 10 points, name this sister of Susano’o who is the Shinto sun goddess.
tossups.answer: Amaterasu [or Amaterasu-no-Omikami] <WA, Myths/Legends>

tossups.question: A form of this property was discovered by Horst Prinzbach’s group while synthesizing dodecahedrane from pagodane (“puh-GO-dane”) derivatives. Anastrozole (“ann-ASS-truh-zole”) inhibits an enzyme named for this property that converts testosterone into estrogen. Molecules with this property have high chemical shifts for their hydrogen atoms due to the creation of a (*) diamagnetic current. The creation of this property is the reason why cyclopentadiene has an unusually low pKa (“P-K-A”) of 16. Molecules with this property have 4n-plus-2 pi electrons according to Hückel’s rule. For 10 points, name this kind of stability in a cyclic system with delocalized electrons, such as benzene.
tossups.answer: aromaticity [or aromatic compounds; prompt on resonance or delocalization or delocalized] <RN, Chemistry>

tossups.question: In “A Certain Tendency of the French Cinema,” François Truffaut (“true-FOH”) claims that a film of this title prompted the French to make Pépé le Moko in a “frank plagiarism of the American cinema.” That film of this title opens with screens asking “What are you going to do about it?” before segueing (“SEG-way-ing”) into a three-minute continuous shot, and was adapted from an Armitage Trail novel by Howard Hawks. Another film of this title cuts between shots of a man kissing a woman in a blue bikini in his car and of Angel’s face as he is (*) dismembered by a chainsaw. In that film of this title, a man asks “You wanna play rough?” before grabbing a grenade launcher and firing at Sosa’s men, yelling “Say hello to my little friend!” For 10 points, give this title of a 1983 Brian de Palma film that stars Al Pacino as a Cuban drug lord.
tossups.answer: Scarface <WA, Other Arts: Film>

tossups.question: Geoffrey Elton’s book The Practice of History criticized E. H. Carr’s book What is History? for arbitrarily distinguishing between “historical” and “of the past” examples of these things. A sociological example of these things consists of institutions and norms external to an actor that constrain their actions. John Searle (“surl”) argued that collective intentionality, assignment of function, and constitutive (“CON-stih-TOO-tiv”) rules create the distinction between classes of these things labeled “brute” and “institutional.” The (*) Rules of Sociological Method, by Émile Durkheim (“ay-MEEL dur-KEM”), calls sociology the “science” of “social” examples of these things. Max Weber (“VAY-bur”) rejected the ethical naturalism of his contemporaries by upholding Hume’s distinction between these things and values. For 10 points, name these objectively true statements often contrasted with fictions.
tossups.answer: facts [accept social facts or historical facts or facts of the past or fact–value distinction] <AA, Social Science: Socio/Anthro>

tossups.question: In 2018, this company was condemned after reports that it contracted the Lovelace Research Institute to conduct experiments on live Java monkeys. Three executives from this company were indicted in September 2019 for holding back market-moving information. For several years starting in 2009, this company programmed its TDI technology to recognize the EPA’s FTP-75 cycles, such that they would only activate controls in the laboratory and thus limit (*) engine output. As a result, those vehicles built by this company put out 40 times more nitrogen oxide in real life compared to during emissions testing, resulting in a scandal that brought down CEO Mark Winterkorn. For 10 points, name this German auto manufacturer whose former products include the Beetle.
tossups.answer: Volkswagen [prompt on VW] <WA, Other Academic>

tossups.question: In this country, 192 olive and cypress trees constitute a “Forest of Remembrance” that was created after a terrorist attack. After his assassination in a bombing, one politician from this country was nicknamed as this country’s “first astronaut.” In this country, a car was launched over a building during Operation Ogre, which assassinated a leader of the far right búnker faction, Luis (*) Carrero Blanco. The pro-Iraq War Popular Party and its leader, José María Aznar, were defeated in this country’s elections after a 2004 terror attack that targeted a train in its capital. This country’s paramilitary Guardia Civil (“GWAR-dyah see-VEEL”) fought the ETA (“ET-ah”), which was dedicated to achieving independence for a region centered on this country’s city of Bilbao. For 10 points, name this country home to Basque and Catalan separatist groups.
tossups.answer: Spain [or España] <ML, European History>

tossups.question: In one play, a character whispers that he has hidden one of these objects in a cellar during a conversation with a nurse in which he laments not having eaten noodles for ages. At the end of that play’s third act, a man tosses one of these objects on the floor and collapses in a chair after struggling over it with Helena. At the end of another play, Doctor Dorn claims one of his medicine bottles made a sound that was actually from one of these objects, in order to calm (*) Irina Arkadina (“ar-KAH-dee-nah”). A hypothetical one of these objects that is hung on a wall in the first act names a literary maxim according to which every element of a story should contribute to its plot. For 10 points, give these objects, the subject of an Anton Chekhov proverb stating that if one is introduced to a play, it must be fired later.
tossups.answer: guns [accept Chekhov’s gun; accept pistol or rifle] (The plays are Uncle Vanya and The Seagull.) <WA, Drama>  If the game is tied at this point, report to your tournament director for tiebreaker instructions.   Bonuses

bonuses.leadin: This author called his lover and collaborator Margarete Steffin his “little teacher” in a group of poems written after her 1941 death. For 10 points each:
answers: Nazi Party [or National Socialist German Workers’ Party; or NSDAP]
parts: Name this author and husband of actress Helene Weigel (“hay-LAY-nuh VYE-gul”) whose poem “The Solution” satirically asks why his government didn’t choose to “dissolve the people and elect another” after facing opposition.

A poem by Brecht ends with a writer pleading “Burn me!” after learning that this party [emphasize] did not burn his books. Brecht wrote his most celebrated plays while living in exile during this political party’s rule.
This author’s book Peeling the Onion revealed his role in the Waffen-SS. This author published the novel Crabwalk shortly after winning the 1999 Nobel.

bonuses.leadin: Both Alonzo Church and a landmark paper “On Computable Numbers” proved that no general algorithm can solve the Entscheidungsproblem (“en-CHY-doonks-prob-LAME”), Hilbert’s German term for these problems. For 10 points each:
answers: decision problem [or word forms like decide, decidable, decidability, undecidable, or undecidability]
parts: Give the English term for computational problems whose answer is either yes or no, which are more convenient to study than search or optimization problems. A form of this term is a synonym of “solvability.”

The computational formalism consisting of a moving tape head that reads and writes symbols was a “machine” devised for that second proof by this prosecuted mathematician and code-breaker. The largest British banknote will bear his face.

A decision problem is defined to be NP-complete if it is in these two classes. One requires the existence of a polynomial-time certificate, while the other requires a polynomial-time reduction [emphasize] from any NP-complete problem.

bonuses.leadin: The outcome of a failure of this activity is referred to as a BATNA (“bat-nuh”). For 10 points each:
answers: negotiation [or negotiating; accept principled negotiation; do not accept or prompt on other answers]
zero-sum situation [or zero-sum game; prompt on Pareto optimality until “Pareto” is read] <WA, Social Science: Socio/Anthro>
parts: Give this activity. A “principled” approach to this activity is advocated by Roger Fisher and William Ury in Getting to Yes, which suggests such strategies as “Focus on interests, not positions.”

A somewhat similar theory of negotiation is called this psychologist’s namesake “argument” and suggests using empathetic listening to find common ground. This psychologist invented client-centered therapy.
Negotiation can be difficult in this sort of situation, in which the gain of one party implies an equal loss on the part of the other party. Games named for having this property are Pareto-optimal.

bonuses.leadin: Epidemics of smallpox and cocoliztli (“ko-ko-LEEST-lee”) are major complications in trying to estimate the early modern population of this broad region. For 10 points each:
answers: America [or the Americas; or North and South America; accept New World or Western Hemisphere]
Borah [accept Woodrow Borah or William Borah] <JM, Commonwealth/Misc>
parts: Name this region whose history is divided into “pre-Columbian” and “Columbian” eras, which likely had 90 to 95 percent of its population killed by smallpox. The earliest estimates of this two-continent region’s pre-contact population hovered around 2 million.

This 16th-century Spanish priest was an early proponent of a “high count” of pre-Columbian populations, estimating that 8 million people lived in Haiti before Columbus’s arrival. He defended Indian rights in the Valladolid (“vah-yah-doh-LEED”) Debates.

The “high count” school was repopularized in the 1970s by a Berkeley historian with this surname who partnered with Sherburne Cook. An Idaho senator with this surname led the “irreconcilables” faction in the Senate in opposing the League of Nations.

bonuses.leadin: You are a young, devout Muslim man who is interested in marrying his equally devout Mormon girlfriend. For 10 points each:
answers: alcohol [or equivalents like booze; prompt on strong drink or hot beverage or intoxicating beverage]
People of the Book [or Ahl al-Kitab; do not accept or prompt on “dhimmi”]
parts: One of the easier aspects of the marriage to negotiate will be what’s in the fridge, because both religions prohibit the consumption of this type of liquid.

It’s less clear whether your marriage is permissible at all, because Mormons are generally not considered to be part of this category of recognized monotheistic believers, whom Muslim men [emphasize] are allowed to marry. Zoroastrians, Jews, and Christians are considered to belong to this category.

If you can’t get a qadi or Islamic court judge to bless your marriage, you might get it approved by one of these clerics who can issue fatwas. A “grand” one of them is the leading Islamic jurist in many countries.

bonuses.leadin: In both biology and engineering, transducers convert these things between different forms, such as between electromagnetic waves and electrical currents. For 10 points each:
answers: step functions [accept step response or step input; accept Heaviside step function] <WA, Applied Math/Misc>
parts: Give this generic term that, in engineering, refers to any function that conveys information. The strength of these things is quantified by the ratio of them “to noise.”

This quantity measures a signal’s change in magnitude due to an amplifier or controller, and it is typically measured in decibels in signal processing. Like phase, it is plotted against frequency on a Bode plot.

The DC gain of a system is given by the ratio of two of these types of functions, representing a unit response and a unit input respectively. The derivative of this type of function is a Dirac delta function.

bonuses.leadin: A phrase drawn from this song titles Edmund Wilson’s anthology of Civil War Literature, Patriotic Gore. For 10 points each:
answers: “Maryland, My Maryland” [accept descriptions like the Maryland state song or Maryland anthem]
parts: Name this song composed in response to the xenophobic Pratt Street Riot. It encourages citizens to “Remember Carroll’s Sacred Trust” by joining the Confederate cause.

The Pratt Street Riot was led in part by this faction of anti-war Northern Democrats led by Clement Vallandigham. This faction’s name comes from an incident in which a Confederate supporter mailed two live snakes to Washington, DC.

The Pratt Street Riots and broader Confederate sympathies in Maryland were the catalyst for the passage of a bill that allowed the federal government to suspend this right, thus allowing the defendant of the case Ex parte Merryman to be arrested without charge.

bonuses.leadin: The speaker of a sonnet imagines fondly asking “Doth God exact day-labour” before describing this thing “denied.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this thing that represents the speaker’s eyesight in the sonnet “On His Blindness,” which opens, “When I consider how [this thing] is spent.”
This author of “On His Blindness” wrote, “Long is the way and hard, that out of Hell leads up to the light” in his epic poem Paradise Lost.

Book I of Paradise Lost describes the flames of hell giving off “no light but rather” this two-word phrase. William Styron’s struggle with depression is recounted in a Vanity Fair “Memoir of Madness” titled for this phrase.

bonuses.leadin: In the early 1950s, Igor Stravinsky used this compositional technique for his Septet and ballet Agon, claiming that it let him pick his own “building materials.” For 10 points each:
answers: serialism [or serialist; accept twelve-tone serialism; prompt on twelve-tone technique]
Darmstadt [accept Darmstadt School or Darmstadt International Summer Courses for New Music]
parts: Name this technique that uses strict orderings of pitches and sometimes other musical elements. Most pieces by Karel Goeyvaerts (“Carl GOO-ee-varts”), Karlheinz Stockhausen (“SHTOCK-how-zin”), and Pierre Boulez (“boo-LEZZ”) use this technique.
The Italian serialist Luigi Nono identified a school of total serialist composers, including Stockhausen and Boulez, who regularly attended this city’s International Summer Courses for New Music.
This Austrian composer died in 1951, just as the twelve-tone serialism techniques he pioneered were becoming all the rage. He composed Pierrot Lunaire (“p’yair-OH loo-NAIR”) and Transfigured Night.

bonuses.leadin: The protagonist realizes that he has transformed into one of this author’s characters upon waking up in an entry from the 2014 collection Men Without Women. For 10 points each:
answers: Franz Kafka [accept Kafka On the Shore or Umibe no Kafuka] (The story is “Samsa in Love.”)
“Barn Burning” [or “Naya wo Yaku”; do not accept or prompt on “Burning”] <RK, Short Fiction>
parts: Name this author. He titles a 2002 novel whose characters include a 15-year-old runaway, whose alter-ego is “The Boy Named Crow,” and Satoru Nakata, who can communicate with cats.

Haruki Murakami, the author of those works, also wrote a story titled for this character in which a nurse tells the disabled Habara a story after each of their sexual encounters, paralleling this narrator of Arabian Nights.

A Faulkner story about Abner Snopes shares this title with a Murakami story about a man who reconciles with his former lover, whose new boyfriend enjoys the destructive title activity. Both stories inspired a similarly-titled 2018 adaptation by Lee Chang-Dong.

bonuses.leadin: Strabo records that Hannibal made a pilgrimage to Lake Avernus in order to make a sacrifice to this deity. For 10 points each:
answers: Pluto [or Plouton; prompt on, but DO NOT REVEAL, Hades]
parts: Name this primarily Roman god whose name derives from a Greek world for wealth. He is commonly shown holding a horn of plenty.
Pluto originated as a distinct figure in Roman tradition, but he shares several key tales with this Greek god of the underworld, such as the abduction of Proserpine.

The Romans conflated Pluto and Hades with other underworld gods, such as Dis Pater and this god, who names an Etruscan tomb that includes the only known depiction of the demon Tuchulcha (“too-CULL-kuh”). This Roman god, who punished broken oaths, is the ultimate source of the name of one of Tolkien’s fictional races.

bonuses.leadin: Cyclosporine drops, under the brand name Restasis (“ree-STAY-siss”), are used to increase the production of this substance, whose evaporation is prevented by the secretion of the Mebomian gland. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this substance that is secreted from the lacrimal glands next to the eyes.
This enzyme found in tears destroys peptidoglycan. A form of this enzyme found in hen eggs is commonly used for research purposes.

Transgenic forms of hen egg lysozyme are often conjugated to one of these compounds in immunization experiments. This term designates small molecules that induce an immune response when conjugated to a larger one.

bonuses.leadin: This novel begins with the protagonist’s mother telling her “You must not tell anyone what I am about to tell you.” For 10 points each:
answers: ghosts (That work is The Turn of the Screw.)
Chinese-American [prompt on Chinese or American; prompt on Asian-American; prompt on Han Chinese] <RK, Long Fiction>
parts: Name this novel. In its frequently-excerped first chapter, the protagonist’s mother describes how her aunt committed suicide after being shunned by her village for giving birth in wedlock.

That chapter, titled “No-Name Woman,” ends by describing one of these figures. An unnamed governess encounters one of these figures shortly before Miles dies in her arms at the end of a Henry James novella.
The Woman Warrior was written by Maxine Hong Kingston, an author of this ethnicity. Women of this ethnicity are followed in the vignettes of the novel The Joy Luck Club.

bonuses.leadin: This city became prosperous due to a massive iron mine and furnace, which supplied much of the wealth of the Kingdom of Kush. For 10 points each:
answers: Zulu Kingdom [or Zululand; or kwaZulu] <JM, World History>
parts: Name this city home to a number of steeply sloped pyramids that succeeded Napata as Kush’s capital after Napata was sacked by the Egyptians. This city also names two scripts, a hieroglyphic one and a cursive one, used throughout ancient Nubia.

Iron smelting was also discovered remarkably early by the Nok culture of this modern-day country. The sacred city of Ife (“ee-fay”) was likely established by Nok descendents in this country, also home to the city of Kano.
Shaka, a ruler of this kingdom in modern South Africa, innovated by expanding the iron piece on the end of its traditional weapon, the assegai, to make the iklwa (“EEK-wah”).

bonuses.leadin: This artist called photography a medium “which lies, for in reality time does not stop.” For 10 points each:
answers: Alfred Stieglitz (That photograph is The Steerage.)
Sioux (“soo”) [or Lakota; or Dakota] <RK, Other Arts: Misc>
parts: Name this artist who Gertrude Käsebier (“KAZZ-uh-beer”) captured placing his hand on one of his artworks. While in Paris, Edward Steichen (“STY-kin”) depicted one of this artist’s works in the photos The Open Sky, 11 P.M. and The Silhouette—4 A.M.

Gertrude Käsebier and Edward Steichen practiced the Pictorialist style championed by this organizer of Gallery 291 in his journal Camera Work. In one of his photos, a white drawbridge divides upper and lower crowds of people.

When she wasn’t championing women in photography, Käsebier was often photographing people of this Native American group. An ethnographic study conducted by Edward Curtis includes photos of their chief Sitting Bull.

bonuses.leadin: In 2011, scientists at Chalmers University made the first observation of the dynamical form of this effect, in which an accelerating moving mirror generates microwave photons. For 10 points each:
answers: traveling faster than the speed of light [or traveling faster than the local speed of light in the medium; or superluminal travel; or equivalents] <RN, Physics>
parts: Name this effect in which the presence of virtual particles in and around a pair of narrowly-separated parallel plates generates an attractive force between them.
The Casimir effect is explained by the polarization of this entity. Evacuating the air from a jar is used to approximately create this entity, which is a region of space devoid of matter.

In the Scharnhorst effect, signals traveling between two Casimir plates can have this property because the index of refraction between the plates is less than one. In Cherenkov radiation, electrons in a nuclear reactor have this property.

bonuses.leadin: Charles Homer Haskins introduced the historiographic concept of a “renaissance” of this century. For 10 points each:
answers: Charlemagne [or Karl der Grosse or Charles the Great or Carolus Magnus; prompt on Charles or Karl or Carolus; prompt on Carolingian minuscule or Caroline minuscule] <JM, European History>
parts: Name this century during which the founding of the Hanseatic League and the University of Paris expanded European trade and science. Henry II of England presided over a time of prosperity during this century.

The 12th-century renaissance followed an 11th-century boom in building these things. The first joint-stock company was established by a group of Parisian proprietors of these things, whose proprietors had a reputation for unscrupulousness.
Another medieval “renaissance” was named for this first Holy Roman Emperor, who was crowned in Aachen (“OCK-in”) in 800 CE. This ruler’s advisors wrote in his namesake “minuscule” script.

bonuses.leadin: Some artists were just too good at depicting reality. For 10 points each:
answers: Giotto [or Giotto di Bondone; or Giottus]
parts: Vasari’s Lives recalls how this Proto-Renaissance artist painted such a convincing fly that his teacher Cimabue (“chee-MAH-boo-ay”) tried to brush the fly off the canvas. This artist impressed Pope Benedict XI by drawing a perfect circle freehand.
Renaissance painters often used the techniques of quadratura and di sotto in sù to create illusionistic depth, making it seem like paintings in these parts of buildings extended to the heavens.

This ancient Greek artist challenged a rival to make a more realistic painting after birds pecked at his still-life of some grapes. That rival bested him when this artist tried to pull back some curtains to view the painting, only to realize that the curtains [emphasize] were the painting.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about the radical 11th-century philosopher al-Ma’ari, a philosopher who pissed off al-Qaeda so much that they beheaded his statue, for 10 points each.
answers: Deism [do not accept or prompt on “theism”]
anti-natalism [prompt on answers like being against birth by asking “what is the specific philosophical term?”] <JM, Phil/Thought>
parts: al-Ma’ari viewed the Quran as a “set of idle tales,” instead choosing to express this sort of view of God. Many of the Founding Fathers held this view, which is often said to limit God’s role to a “divine watchmaker.”

al-Ma’ari was very accomplished in this literary form, whose practitioners should be expelled from an ideal city according to Plato’s Republic. Major practitioners of this form who dabbled in philosophy include Samuel Taylor Coleridge.

al-Ma’ari also held this philosophical position, which has been expounded by South African philosopher David Benatar in such books as The Human Predicament. This position holds that procreation is immoral.

bonuses.leadin: These things are fairly ubiquitous in many Andean cities, where they are often referred to as micros (“MEE-krows”). For 10 points each:
answers: shared taxis [or vans or minibuses or fixed-route taxis or anything that conveys this general idea; prompt on taxis or jitneys or buses; do not accept “rideshare” or “mototaxi” or the names of rideshare companies like Uber]
parts: Describe these things, called marshrutka (“mar-SHROOT-ka”) in the former Soviet Union, matatu in East Africa, and service (“ser-VEESE”) or sherut (“sheh-ROOT”) in the Middle East. Studies show that they often approximate the routes that would otherwise be taken by subways.

This capital city’s transit needs are mostly served by shared taxis, since a civil war between a Maronite dominated government and Sunni and Shiite militias unfortunately destroyed its transit infrastructure in the 1980s.

Collective taxis are the only form of transit linking cities like Ramallah, Nablus, and Bethlehem in this region because Israel controls the territory between them. Along with the Gaza Strip, this region is under the jurisdiction of the Palestinian Authority.
